title: Introduction to some other distributions
text:
The exponential distribution models the time between events in a Poisson process, where events occur continuously and independently at a constant average rate. It is often used to model waiting times, such as the time between arrivals at a queue.


The PDF of an exponential distribution is: \[
f(x; \lambda) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x},x \geq 0
\]


Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor.

from scipy.stats import expon
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

lambda_val = 1
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 1000)
y = lambda_val * np.exp(-lambda_val * x)

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.title('Exponential Distribution')
plt.xlabel('Time')
plt.ylabel('Probability Density')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
text:
Section 1: Normal Distribution 
The normal distribution is one of the most common probability distributions in statistics. It is a continuous distribution defined by its mean \(\mu\) standard deviation \(\sigma\). The normal distribution is symmetric around the mean.

Subsection 1.1: Details 
Probability Density Function:
\[
f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left( - \frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2 \sigma^2} \right)
\]

Where:



\(\mu\) is the mean


\(\sigma\) is the standard deviation


It is also central to the Central Limit Theorem.1

title: Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
text:
Section 2: Poisson Distribution


Definition of the Poisson Distribution:

The Poisson distribution models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time or space. It assumes that these events happen at a constant rate and independently of each other.


Applications of the Poisson Distribution:

It is commonly used to model phenomena such as the number of phone calls received in an hour.

title: Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
text:
Section 3: Feature Comparison Table








Distribution
Description
Parameters




Normal
Models continuous data, symmetric around the mean.
Mean \(\mu\), Standard Deviation \(\sigma\)


Poisson
Models the count of events in a fixed interval.
Rate \(\mu\)



The probability density function of the normal distribution is given by: \(f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left( - \frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2 \sigma^2} \right)\) , while The probability mass function of the Poisson distribution is given by: \(P(X = k) = \frac{\lambda^k e^{-\lambda}}{k!}\)

The normal distribution is continuous and models variables like height or temperature with a symmetric, bell-shaped curve, while the Poisson distribution is discrete and models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval, like the number of calls received per hour.

title: Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
Introduction to different probability distributions in Statistics
text:
Footnotes


Central Limit Theorem states that the sum of many independent and identically distributed random variables tends to be normally distributed, regardless of their original distribution.↩︎

title: Introduction to Binomial Distribution
text:
Basic Information

Theory:


The binomial distribution describes the number of successes in a fixed number of independent trials, each with the same probability of success. It is a discrete distribution and is commonly used to model scenarios like flipping a coin or answering multiple-choice questions.

title: Introduction to Binomial Distribution
text:
Equations and Graphs
Probability Mass Function: \[
P(X = k) = \binom{n}{k} p^k (1 - p)^{n - k}
\]
An example of binomial distribution plot:

title: Introduction to Binomial Distribution
text:
Other Information


A more detailed explanation of binomial distribution can be found in (Jacobs and Archie 2008).









Jacobs, Jeff, and Tim Archie. 2008. “Investigating Sense of Community in First-Year College Students.” Journal of Experiential Education 30 (3): 282–85.
